channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: DealBook: After Crisis, Iceland Holds a Tight Grip on Its Banks
item.description: Iceland is a living experiment in what can happen when a country forces its financial firms to go under, rather than bailing them out.
item.dc:creator: By NATHANIEL POPPER
item.media:description: Bjarni Benediktsson, Iceland's minister of finance, recently came into office after an election that hinged on economic discontent.

item.title: Obama’s Path From Critic to Overseer of Spying
item.description: As a young lawmaker, Barack Obama vowed to rein in a surveillance state run amok. More than six years later, he is now the commander in chief presiding over a surveillance state.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: In ’07, then-Senator Obama spoke disapprovingly at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars about spying.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Baseball Diplomacy in Cuba
item.description: Last year’s college championship team from the University of Tampa played an exhibition game against a Cuban youth squad on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Sudan: Gunfire at U.N. Base Kills One and Wounds Dozens
item.description: Peacekeepers fired warning shots to keep the gunmen out of the base, the United Nations said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Success Claimed in Test of Weapons-Delivery System
item.description: China’s Defense Ministry said that it had successfully tested a glider that can travel many times the speed of sound, following a report in the online Washington Free Beacon.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: French Leader’s Policy Proposals Seek Centrist Path
item.description: Europe’s Socialist standard-bearer, President François Hollande, who campaigned against austerity policies, has received praise from the European Union and Germany for his plan to reduce spending.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: President François Hollande, whose economic plans have been praised by the European Union, said his views have not shifted.

item.title: Early Tallies Show Revised Charter Passing in Egypt
item.description: A revised Constitution validating the military takeover in Egypt appeared headed for approval, according to early tabulations, as international monitors questioned the fairness of the vote.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A judge in Cairo counted ballots Wednesday in a referendum seen as giving electoral legitimacy to the military takeover.

item.title: A Quandary for Mexico as Vigilantes Rise
item.description: In Michoacán State, where vigilantes battle drug cartel gunmen, Mexican officials face a decision on whether to disarm the loosely organized groups or allow them to continue fighting.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz-Perez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives mourn a man killed Tuesday in Antúnez, Mexico, after soldiers moved in to disarm vigilantes. Residents view the fighters as conquering heroes.

item.title: Israel’s Efforts to Limit Use of Holocaust Terms Raise Free-Speech Questions
item.description: A measure making it a crime to call someone a Nazi battles the trivialization of an atrocity, but not everyone agrees this is the way to proceed.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dov Lipman, a rabbi and a sponsor of the bill, has had the word Nazi flung at him.

item.title: Indian School Ensnared in U.S. Diplomatic Row
item.description: The American Embassy School, popular with expatriates in New Delhi, is facing questions from the Indian government in the latest volley in its diplomatic spat with the United States.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Analysis: A Fine Line Between Summer Sizzle and Too Darn Hot
item.description: As the soccer world sweats and frets at the prospect of a summer World Cup in Qatar, the rest of the sports world gets on with business at usual: making elite athletes perform in extreme heat.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY
item.media:description: During the first week of this year’s Australian Open, where temperatures have sometimes soared past 100 degrees, players such as Maria Sharapova have used ice towels.

item.title: Chinese Activists Test New Leader and Are Crushed
item.description: About 20 people associated with the New Citizens Movement have been detained after calling for a fight against injustice and official corruption.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Xu Zhiyong was indicted last month for “gathering a crowd to disrupt public order” and faces almost certain conviction.

item.title: Video Shows U.S. Soldier Long Held by Afghans
item.description: A video of an American held captive for four and a half years has been obtained by the U.S. government, and officials said that it showed him in declining health.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the only American being held captive in Afghanistan, in a video released in 2010.

item.title: Benghazi Attack Called Avoidable in Senate Report
item.description: A stinging report by the Senate Intelligence Committee blames both American diplomats and spies for poor communication and lax security before the deadly 2012 episode in Libya.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI, ERIC SCHMITT and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Hnaider Journal: Lebanese Bomber’s Death, and Life, Leave Questions
item.description: Qutaiba al-Satem, implicated in a bombing, has become the face of what many Lebanese fear: citizens radicalized by the Syrian conflict. But in the village where he grew up, the picture is murkier.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: In Hnaider, Lebanon, friends and family mourning Qutaiba al-Satem, who was said to be the bomber in an attack this month in the Beirut area.

item.title: Militants Unleash Wave of Violence in Iraq, Killing Dozens
item.description: The latest deaths brought the number of people killed in the last three days to more than 80.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and DURAID ADNAN
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Salah Abdel-Hassan, a mechanic, stood at the site of a car bomb attack on Wednesday in Baghdad's Karrada neighborhood.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Whose Mall Is It?
item.description: The Brazilian elite see favela-dwelling vagrants. I see ordinary teenagers.
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: Donors Offer $2.4 Billion to Aid Syrian Civilians, but U.N. Says More Is Needed
item.description: Western nations, Arab states and others pledged the aid as Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said that $6.5 billion was needed to help Syrian civilians this year.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Pablo Martinez Monsivais
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry delivered remarks at a conference in Kuwait on Wednesday.

item.title: The Lede: Republican Ideas on Immigration Could Legalize Up to 6.5 Million, Study Says
item.description: “Half a loaf” proposals may put many more on a so-called path to citizenship than immigrant advocates have previously thought.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: A Dream Action Coalition demonstration last month.

item.title: Flow of Westerners to Syria Prompts Security Concerns
item.description: Western officials say they are worried that the civil war in Syria could create a cohort of radicalized young people, experienced with warfare, who hold European or American passports.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Arab Neighbors Take Split Paths in Constitutions
item.description: Tunisia and Egypt, whose revolts ignited the Arab Spring, provide a dual lesson in the pitfalls and potentials for democracy in the region as they move toward new charters.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Tuesday, soldiers helped a man into a polling station in Cairo, where Egyptians were set to vote in the third referendum on the constitution in three years.

item.title: Global Piracy Hits Lowest Level Since 2007, Report Says
item.description: The International Maritime Bureau attributed the drop mostly to a sharp decline in piracy off Somalia’s coast.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Financier Says He’s Guilty of Everything but a Crime
item.description: Florian Homm, a former fund manager from Germany who faces extradition to the United States on security fraud, has willfully documented his rise and fall.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Florian Homm steadfastly denies the criminal charges, which are serious enough to keep him in jail for decades.

item.title: Pope Names Cardinals to Oversee Vatican Bank
item.description: Pope Francis replaced all but one of the appointees made by his predecessor, Benedict XVI, in another example of how the new pope is consolidating power.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Tensions Between Afghanistan and U.S. Increase as Airstrike Kills Civilians
item.description: A coalition airstrike in a province north of Kabul killed at least two villagers, prompting President Hamid Karzai to order an inquiry.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
